fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15219].
  {panel}

When a user selects a Project (say ProjX) and Issue Type (eg Task) in the "Create New Issue" wizard, then JIRA remembers these two values in the user's session as the 
last selected Project and last selected Issue Type.
Next time the user creates a new issue, then these two values are used to initialise the selected values.
If the user browses a project or issue, then the selected Project is changed accordingly (eg to ProjY), while the "selected issue type" remains the same.
When the user now clicks "create new issue", JIRA initialises the Project to ProjY, and the issue type to Task, unless Task is not a valid issue type for that project.
In this case, it just defaults to the first issue type in the list.
This is inconsistent with other behaviour, and it would be better if the "default issue type" for the Project was used in this case.
fields.summary: When JIRA sets intitial values for "Create New Issue", and the "last selected issue type" is not valid for the "selected Project", it should use the default Issue type for the Project.

fields.description:
Under certain circumstances, the following behaviour is observed:
When a user selects "Create new Issue", the project is correctly defaulted to the "currently selected" project, however the default issue type for this project is not set correctly.
If the user now selects a different project, then the Issue type will be changed to the default correctly.

Note that  this seems to work mostly, but can be replicated with at least one customer's data.

h3.Steps to reproduce:
(requires at least 2 projects with different Issue Type Schemes and different Issue Type defaults):
- Create projectA, with IssueTypeSchemeA and default Issue Type TypeA, as well as, projectB, with IssueTypeSchemeB and default Issue Type TypeB
- In a fresh user session, select ProjectA and then try to create an issue
projectA and it's default issue type (typeA) will be selected on the create issue screen. go ahead and create an issue with this settings.
- Then select another projectB, and go back to create issue screen.

h3. Expected Behaviour:
The currently selected projectB will be selected in the Create issue screen, with it's own default IssueType TypeB

h3. Actual Behaviour:
The currently selected projectB will be selected in the Create issue screen, but the Issue Type field will recall the last selected Issue Type in this session (which was selected when creating an issue under another project having a different IssueTypeScheme in this case TypeA).
Except of course that typeA is not available in the IssueTypeScemeB, in which case it reverts back to ProjectB's default issue. type.
fields.summary: Sometimes the default Issue Type is not set correctly when creating an Issue.

fields.description:
Although rare, it has been reported by at least one customer that duplicate Issues Keys may be created.

By looking at the code it seems that this may be possible under the following circumstances:
* A request to create an issue is received and gets the relevant project from the Project Manager.
* The Project Manager refreshes its cache of Projects.
* A second request to create an issue is received and gets the new Project object.
* Now, the two separate instances of Project can try to use the same key.

This is all dependant on concurrent operations happening in a particular sequence, and would be more likely to happen on a JIRA server that was under high load.
fields.summary: Duplicate Issue Keys can be created

fields.description:
Hi Atlassian

My initial requirements were to be able :
* to display errors raised by validator defined in the initial-action.
* to define a validator verifying that at least one of two fields was entered during the Create or Edit action.  

Following [my post|http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=26740] done on JIRA Dev. Forum, I made more investigations ...

It appears that :
* Validators, defined in an inital-action of a Workflow, are executed during the *doExecute()*,
* Only *InvalidInputException* raised during *doValidate()* (resulting from Field validation depending on FieldConfiguration) are interpreted to provide a focus on the field in error.

I developped an enhancement described in [KAAM-190|http://developer.atlassian.com/jira/browse/KAAM-190]

Let me known about your opinion.

Rgds
Vincent
fields.summary: Implement Workflow Validator on Edit Action

fields.description:
If the date format is configured with Lower Case m's entered to signify  the months (Example: *d/mm/yyyy h:mm* rather than d/MM/...) during the CSV import, the date displayed for the issues once imported will be incorrect:

Example: Using the following format: *d/mm/yyyy h:mm* with the date in the CSV file as follows: 29/May/08 - The actual date displayed for the issue will be: 29/Jan/08.  For any date imported with this format the month will appear as *Jan*.

JIRA doesn't seen to be able to handle this very well - 

JIRA should either allow this and recognise that if a Lower Case m is within a date it should recognise it as a month.  Or, the import of these dates should fail and produce an error message stating that Upper Case is required.  Rather than allowing the date to  import and display it as *Jan*.  Excel doesn't make this distinction allowing all lower case characters within date formats.
fields.summary: Configure JIRA to recognise Lower Case m's as months within the date formats entered during CSV import.

fields.description:
Firstly, the main problem here is that the end result is unexpected and non-intuitive to users.

1. Create a new project
2. Create a new issue type
3. Add a custom field that only applies to just that issue type
4. Create a few issues in the new project with values in the new custom field
5. Add the custom field to your Issue Navigator as a new column

When you create a query for the project, the new column is not displayed unless you also select the new issue type as part of the filter. Selecting "Any" doesn't help either.

So we have a case where all the issues in the new project are allowed to have the new custom field, but it *still* won't be displayed in the results. Most unexpected.
fields.summary: Columns don't appear in reports when the field is for specific issue types

fields.description:
The OSWorkflow framework provides the ability to create shared transitions in the workflow, which are incredibly useful for creating clean workflows. The feature saves the administrator time (because transition conditions and post functions are configured in the one place), and avoids the risk with inconsistent workflow transitions.

Can we improve the workflow editor interface to allow the definition of shared transitions? Currently I'm doing this very frequently via the workflow XML and it doesn't save much time.
fields.summary: Add ability to define shared transitions in the workflow interface editor

fields.description:
If JIRA would allow me to create an actual hierarchy of issues (not just sub-tasks, it should go down to sub-sub-sub-sub...tasks), then it will have everything I need for Requirements Management in JIRA

The features I would need are:
- ability to set "parent" issue when creating an issue
- ability to view Project issues as a tree
- automatic issue resolution when all child issues are resolved

Example of issue hierarchy:

+ ROOT Issue (Type: User requirement): Manage Customers
   + Child Issue (Type: Technical Requirement): Ability to Create Customers
       + Child Issue (Type: Task): Dialog for entering customer data
       + Child Issue (Type: Task): Dialog for entering customer data
   + Child Issue (Type: Technical requirement): Edit Customers
   + Child Issue (Type: Technical requirement): Delete Customers
....
fields.summary: Ability to define a Issue Hierarchy

fields.description:
In a situation where JIRA fails to create a new issue from an email processed by the mail handler, the issue ID is not reused. 

So for e.g. if your currently available issue ID is TST-10 and JIRA for whatever reason fails to process an email that should use this issue ID, JIRA will try to assign to the next new issue issue ID TST-11. 
The issue ID TST-10 is lost and not reused by the system, which in a busy JIRA installation can generate a thousand issue ID gap .

On the top of missing issues ID, the following error in the log file helps to identify this issue.   

BTW. This error can be addressed by configuring the system with consistent character encoding (JVM, JDBC and DB). 

{noformat}

fields.description:
On the edit issue screen, the comment entry field at the bottom says, "an optional comment describing this update". This makes it seem like the comment will be a revision history comment, to be shown in the 'Change History' tab on the issue.

Instead, comments which are made when you update an issue show up as normal comments. This looks a bit odd, when you consider that you end up with a comment stream like this:

* Issue description: "This is a bug"
* Comment #1: "I'd really like this bug to be fixed. You can reproduce it by doing steps 1, 2, 3."
* Comment #2: "Updating affects version"
* Comment #3: "This bug is really annoying. Is it currently scheduled to be fixed?"
* Comment #4: "Increasing priority of bug"

There's no distinction here between comments #1 and #3 which refer to the problem, and #2 and #4 which refer to changes in the issue. Comments #2 and #4 don't actually show the change that happened when the user commented -- you have to switch to the Change History tab for this.

So this view kind of mixes up change comments with comments about the issue itself. I think you should consider making one of two changes:

- making change comments show up on the Change History tab, but not the Comments tab; or
- removing the comment field from the edit issue screen and the workflow screens where it doesn't fit.

There might be a better solution I haven't thought of, however.
fields.summary: Change comments from edit screen appear as normal comments which is confusing and not very useful
Add a link to plugin documentation in atlassian-plugin.xml (and display the link in the plugins admin page)

When you try to start JIRA with a Lucene file lock in place, you get a slightly confusing message because the lock file location is repeated.
Also I think the "SimpleFSLock@" is meaningless to users.

{quote}
An existing index lock was found.

An index lock file was found unexpectedly. This occurs either because JIRA was not cleanly shutdown or because there is another instance of this JIRA installation currently running. Please ensure that no other instance of this JIRA installation is running and then remove the following lock file(s) and restart JIRA:

SimpleFSLock@/home/mlassau/jira/index/issues/write.lock SimpleFSLock@/home/mlassau/jira/index/comments/write.lock

Once restarted you will need to reindex your data to ensure that indexes are up to date.

Do not delete the lock file(s) if there is another JIRA running with the same index directory, instead cleanly shutdown the other instance. 
{quote}
fields.summary: Issue Lock Warning message is slightly incorrect: the lock file path is repeated.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15129].
  {panel}

*The problem*

The mail handler configured in *JIRA > ⚙ > System > Incoming Mail* does not have a functionality that removes signatures from email.
This can be quite an issue when some users reply by email with a huge signature, and a very long comment is added to an existing JIRA ticket. The more comments are added by email, the more a user will have to scroll down in the ticket to get to the relevant information.

*Solution*

Improve the JIRA mail handler to strip email signatures.

*Related issues*
This issue was created based on JRA-15072.
fields.summary: Improve the Mail Handler to remove/strip email signatures

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15128].
  {panel}

This issue just jammed me up and I think it's a terrible UI design to include the "Screens" operation under "View Field Configuration" when that operation applies to ALL field configurations across all schemes without any warning.  We're using the Enterprise Edition and setup a number of unique projects and configurations and I was shocked to find out that in the process of removing screens from one of my configurations that I had copied that I disabled functionality in my other projects.

In my example I had the following setup:
------------
Field Configuration Schemes:
	- Issue Reporting 1 --> Project 1
	- Issue Reporting 2 --> Project 2

Field Configuration:
	- Issue Screen 1
	- Issue Screen 2

Screens:
	- Enter Issue 1 --> Project 1
	- Assign Issue 1 --> Project 1
	- Enter Issue 2 --> Project 2
	- Assign Issue 2 --> Project 2

Field Configuration Issue Screen 1:
	- Assignee -->
		- Enter Issue 1
		- Assign Issue 1
		- Enter Issue 2
		- Assign Issue 2

	- Description -->
		- Enter Issue 1
		- Assign Issue 1
		- Enter Issue 2
		- Assign Issue 2

Field Configuration Issue Screen 2 (copied of Issue Screen 1):
	- Assignee -->
		- Enter Issue 1
		- Assign Issue 1
		- Enter Issue 2
		- Assign Issue 2

	- Description -->
		- Enter Issue 1
		- Assign Issue 1
		- Enter Issue 2
		- Assign Issue 2		
------------

I then went and removed the Assignee and Description from the "Enter Issue 1" and "Assign Issue 1" screens in "Field Configuration Issue Screen 2" and ended up losing all those fields in "Project 1" which uses "Enter Issue 1" and "Assign Issue 1".  Had I seen some sort of warning in bold-red font that I was about to change ALL of my projects, or better yet -- if this action was not even permitted here, I would have never done this.  Putting a note in the documentation is not good enough, you need to have a warning in the UI because it's definitely not clear that you're changing all your projects..... why bother to have separate configuration areas if it's going to affect everything?  The only thing you see on the "Associate field XXXXXX to screens" page is:   "Associate the field XXXXXX to the appropriate screens. You must associate a field to a screen before it will be displayed. New fields will be added to the end of a tab."  No warning at all....

To me it sounds like this UI works good for the non- Enterprise Edition of Jira, which does not allow multiple Field Configurations, and it was just left as is for the Enterprise Edition where it's definitely not sufficient.
fields.summary: View Field Configuration UI should not include the "Screens" operation without a disclaimer since it affects ALL projects/configurations.

fields.description:
When using "v:" or "ff:" to find issues across versions, erroneous results are returned. For example, when entering "ff:7.5" I would expect to see issues with the following fix for versions returned:

* 7.5
* 7.5.1
* 7.5-rc-1

What is actually returned contains not only those version listed above, but also issues that don't have a version with "7.5" in them at all. For example, I'm also getting issues with fix for versions like:

* 6.0.0.0
* 7.6.x

As well as issue that have no fix for version.
fields.summary: Smart Query: "v:" and "ff:" do not work as advertised

fields.description:
Hi,

As of today, the Convert to Issue/Sub Task operation cannot be restricted to:

1. Groups, i.e. we want only specific uses to be able to run this operation using project permission scheme (like with Time Tracking, Comments, etc.).

2. Issue Types, i.e. we would like to restrict the conversion to specific issue types.
For example: 
* Some of our sub issue types are opened automatically by the system (like merge issues that cannot be opened manually)
*  We don't want development tasks to be converted to bugs, etc.

This feature is a very handy one for us and we wanted it  for a long time now, but we cannot use it in our system if we will not be able to restrict it and keep our work methodology intact. 

Let us know if more information is required.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Restriction/Permissions for Covent to Issue/Sub Task operation

fields.description:
Would it be possible to simply encrypt the password sent to the Jira/Confluence server?

At our organization, we have "ONE SINGLE PASSWORD" for everything (which we are forced to change regularly). Our users expect to use this password everywhere (and Jira/Confluence/etc is integrated into our system via Crowd). Our security team does not like that this one single password is passed across the network in plain text by Jira/Confluence/etc, but would accept the situation if it is encrypted in some way.

For us, after authentication, encryption is neither desired nor required, nearly all data should be viewable without restriction. However for changes we prefer to know which user made them, eg who added a comment. We would rather not have to use HTTPS for everything since it adds cost in terms of additional installation/configuration and runtime overhead and we already have published URLs and tools that use only HTTP.

Possible solutions:
* Implement a separate HTTPS only login page perhaps as part of Crowd?
* Use a javascript function to make an MD5 (or other)  hash  using onSubmit() and send that instead? Google found http://pajhome.org.uk/crypt/md5/auth.html as an example.
fields.summary: Encrypt passwords sent from login portlet/page to server.

fields.description:
Most of the charting portlets have a "Days Previously" field that allow you specify a window on the chart in question.  In many cases I find that I'm not interested in a window on my filter - my filter defines the window exactly as I want it.  I'd like to be able to leave the "Days Previously" field blank and have it simply show all the information within the filter.  The initial date can easily be worked out from the earliest creation date of issues within the filter.

As an example, I'd like to use a Created vs Resolved of issues Fixed For my next release.  Our releases happen on an approximately quaterly basis but in the first week of the project I'm only interested in looking at that week's progress and towards the end of a slipping release I want to be able to see the whole of the release's progress and not risk the "90 days previously" clipping off some of the issue creations that happened early on.  At the moment, to acheive this I have to edit my window each time I look at the chart recalculating the appropriate number of Days Previously.
fields.summary: The "Days Previously" field in the charting plugin should be optional

fields.description:
Customer wants to delete a user, but gets the message that the user can't be deleted because he has created several issues. The user clicks on the link that normally displays a list of all the issues this user has created but the query does not find any issues.

The reason is that the user has created issues in projects for which the administrator does not have view permissions, for example when project roles are used and the administrator is not a member.

The "Delete user" dialog should not only display the number of issues this user has created, it should also create a list of affected projects. This way the administrator could modify his permissions accordingly.

At the very least the dialog should display a note saying that the issue list may not show all issues because the administrator does not have suitable permissions.
fields.summary: Can't delete user if the user has created or has issues assigned to them that the administrator does not have permissions to see

fields.description:
Problem Description:

assignee dropdown on workflow postfunction can expend the heap on large installations

An application fatal heap overflow occurs when applying a workflow post-function where the installation has many hundreds of projects and thousands of users. If a post function 'update issue field' is selected, (or possibly other functions which involve dropdown fields rather than user pickers) the rendered html source will include inline all dropdown options - eg. 600 projects x 1,000 users who are assignable to that project. This calculation loop can expend available memory and cause general system slowdown.

Specifically this happens when adding an 'Update Issue Field' post function in a workflow. The "Assign to User" field tries to build a list of all assignable users, however in this case there is no project context so it builds up a list of assignable users _per project_. If a user is assignable in multiple projects, they appear in the list multiple times.

Recommendation: Change the dropdown to a user picker.
fields.summary: Adding Update Issue Field workflow postfunction causes OutOfMemoryError

fields.description:
Error reproduced installing Jira on Windows 2003 (but not when installed over Mac OS X)

Steps to reproduce:

# Create a directory for indexing, and remove permissions for the user JIRA runs with
# Start JIRA installation. On the first page of the setup wizard, specify the index directory - try to use the one without permissions. When trying to accept that, JIRA produces an error message, saying that it has no permissions. Try this step several times.
# Grant permission over the index directory, and continue installation normally.
# Log in as administrator, and go to the services page. Several backup services have been created.

Regards
fields.summary: Multiple backup services created when no permission over index directory during installation

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15110].
  {panel}

Add an email notification service that sent email notification messages to System admins on critical events in the application.

For a small JIRA installations or hosted instances where there are not dedicated webserver administrators and nobody monitor the application, often problems need to become critical before are investigated.

Similary to [JRA-15109|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-15109] there are many advantages of such as feature. 
{quote}
Perhaps the most significant are:

   1. Monitor in a better way "helth" of the application - some of the user don't even know what is a web app server (Tomcat/Reisen) and where to look for the log files.
   2. Diagnose problems in their early stage - e.g. mailhandler issues/misconfiguration are not visible without access to the log file.
   3. Users would attempt to address common and obvious issues listed in the log file if the would have a "convenient" access to the logs.
   4. In overall it should impact number of support request logged in SAC.

Many web based application already include similar features.
{quote}

A simple solution only send the logs or warnings, where complex implementations include ability to set up triggers and monitors on various custom defined events.
fields.summary: Email notification service that notifies System admins on critical events in the application.

fields.description:
There are many situation where JIRA administrators don't have suitable access to a server that host the application to review log files.
A good example of that sort of implementations is JIRA Hosted where "the admins" have access to the application only through web browser.

There are many advantages of such as feature. Perhaps the most significant are:

# Monitor in a better way  "helth" of the application - some of the user don't even know what is a web app server (Tomcat/Reisen) and where to look for the log files.
# Diagnose problems in their early stage - e.g. mailhandler issues/misconfiguration are not visible without access to the log file.
# Users would attempt to address common and obvious issues listed in the log file if the would have a "convenient" access to the logs.
# In overall it should impact number of support request logged in SAC

Many web based application already include similar features.
A simple solution only displays the logs and allows to navigate between pages, where complex implementations include ability to create filters and are able to suggest possible resolutions for the know problems.
fields.summary: Display standard output (application logs) into the Admin console in JIRA

fields.description:
One of our customers (we set up and support their JIRA instance) noticed that their Excel exports from JIRA were not working properly.   They would go into Find Issues and then click the link to export the issue list to an Excel spreadsheet.   When I looked at the Excel spreadsheet, the URL for issue key was wrong.   It was http://127.0.0.1:8080/browse/AVIENH-180.     This is obviously incorrect... it should be http://tasks.aileron..net/browse/AVIENH-180.

I suspected that this is related to the fact that these URLs are being generated using the incoming request URL and not the Base URL specified in the "General Administration" section.     To confirm, changed my Apache mod-proxy config to redirect the incoming requests to tasks.aileron.net:8080 (we run apache with mod_proxy sitting in front of our JIRA server).

After I made this config change and bounced apache, I noticed that the spreadsheet now read:   http://tasks.aileron.net:8080/browse/AVIEN-180.   This is close (but doesn't really work for us since we do not allow direct connectivity to 8080).

Shouldn't JIRA be using the Base URL specified in General Configuration rather than try to use the URL from the incoming HTTP requests?
fields.summary: Export to Excel does not use Base URL in General Configuration to build HyperLink for Issue Key

fields.description:

See support issue JSP-24333 for details

fields.summary: Deleting user from Crowd produces stack-traces for ex-user's issues & filters in Jira
